Most of the stuff you talked about there could easily be cause or effect. You might live longer because you are in love, or you might fall in love because of some hard-to-measure form of prosperity that also causes longer life expectancy.
Also, the value of being happy isn't measured very well by considering how happy being given a certain amount of money would make you. It would be better to calculate how much happiness you could buy with the same money by, say, watching Deadpool in the theater repeatedly, or buying fancier meals or a new car that allows you to feel subtly superior to those around you. In fact, winning money is just a way of buying happiness, and it would be better to consider how much money that average gambler loses before they win such a jackpot. I would guess that long-term love is probably much more valuable than considering a gambler's winnings would make it seem, but on the other hand a gambler might be more materialistic and thus more affected by winning that money than the average person.

Imagine if you will that each person has their own currency based on emotion. Emotion loses its value due to normalization. This means that every time someone normalized being rich, they would become poorer. Their currency would lose value, and their personal economy would undergo inflation. It is important to realize that emotion in reality works nothing like money. One emotion creates the same emotional response in the rest of the brain and across people ( though this can actually depend on the other person's opinions) ergo, you do not exchange emotion. It spreads.

All of these are rare of course, but they happen. Love is a concept, an idea, it's not set in stone and certainly not grounded in reality.

If believe in it and find for yourself, then good on you. But many get betrayed, neglected or just die alone. There's no guarantees or refunds.

Neither yet kinda both. It's just a very idealized fantasy version. You get this (personal observation bias here) when women talk of finding their "Mr Darcy" or Edward or "The One" or wanting a life like the "The Notebook". It's cute, quaint and hopelessly naive. They don't exist, it's fiction. 

Now I'm not so jaded as to think it doesn't exist, it just seems glamorized to an unrealistic standard. Love is brutal, fleeting, chaotic and beyond your control. But the risk is still worth the reward.

Look, if you believe it then great, prove me wrong. Be a guiding light and do it well. 

BUT. It is a very idealized notion you speak of. Circumstance will not always be in your favour, there's a whole other person with all their baggage, doubts, hopes and dreams that has to come along too. And if one of you slips the whole thing can come down. People die, dreams go unfulfilled, insecurities take over. I do believe in love, but nothing is perfect or last forever. The rarity gives it it's value..

I think the main reason you get the drop-off in the happiness-money graph is because we put so much significance on money, but we have lost what money means.
